attributes.title: White Matter, Cognition and Psychotic Like Experiences: Common and Specific  Patterns.
attributes.description: Psychotic experiences are usually associated with major psychiatric disorders, but they also occur in about 5 % of the general healthy population. Because healthy people who have psychotic-like experiences (PLE) are at heightened risk of developing mental disorders, it is important to understand the cause of these symptoms. The present study aims to find support for the framework that abnormalities in connections of the brain (white matter) cause cognitive deficits, which in turn cause a proneness to PLE. To this end, we will look at the mediating quality of general intelligence and processing speed on the relationship between white matter and PLE (research question 1). The second goal of this study is to find out whether any specific white matter abnormalities are associated with PLE (research question 2). To investigate these questions, we will analyse the structural connectomes of 8185 participants sampled by the UK biobank using a cross-sectional design.

q1.value: Minke Bosma, Stephen Lawrie, Simon Cox, Tim Ziermans, Colin Buchanan, Heather Whalley

q2.value:
Research Question 1 

Hypothesis 1
Slower processing speed acts as an intermediate mediator between white matter disturbances (white matter integrity and connectome integration) and lower general cognitive ability.

Hypothesis 2 
Lower general cognitive ability partially mediates the relationship between poorer white matter integrity and the presence of PLE. 

Hypothesis 3 
Lower general cognitive ability partially mediates the relationship between poorer brain integration and the presence of PLE. 




Research Question 2 
The four hypotheses specified below are all non-directional because previous research has provided evidence for both positive and negative associations. The directionality of these associations is therefore not known. 

Hypothesis  1
Altered white matter integrity in the left arcuate fasciculus and the interhemispheric auditory pathway is associated with having auditory hallucinations. 

Hypothesis 2
Altered white matter integrity in the forceps major and inferior longitudinal fasciculus is associated with having visual hallucinations. 

Hypothesis 3 
Altered white matter integrity in the superolateral medial forebrain bundle will is associated with having persecutory delusions. 

Hypothesis 4
Altered white matter integrity of the cingulum bundle is associated with having delusions of reference.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is an observational, cross-sectional population study. The data to be used is provided by UK Biobank, under project number 4844 linked to projects 10279 and 16124.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: The data has been accessed to make sure all the needed information is present. To date, different variables are located in different documents, and so it has not been possible to perform any analyses.

question.value: This study will use data from the second data release of the UK Biobank, which is a cohort of older community-dwelling participants from the United Kingdom and Northern Ireland. More information on recruitment of participants can be found on https://www.ukbiobank.ac.uk/. Participants who indicated to have (had) schizophrenia, schizotypal disorder, induced delusional disorder, schizoaffective disorder, acute and transient psychotic disorder, persistent delusional disorder, other nonorganic psychotic disorder or unspecified nonorganic psychosis will be excluded from our study.

q11.value: The sample size for this study will be 8185 participants. For research question one, these will be divided into two groups: ever had a PLE and never had a PLE. For the analysis of the second research question, the sample will be divided into 5 groups: Ever had an auditory hallucination, ever had a visual hallucination, ever had a persecutory delusion, ever had a delusion of reference and never had a psychotic-like experience. Data from participants who indicate having had more than one sort of PLE will be used in the groups of all the PLE they reported (e.g. if a participant indicated to have had a visual hallucination and an auditory hallucination, their data will be used in both these groups).

q12.value: The sample size of this study will consist of 8185 because this is the number of participants of whom a connectome has been constructed.

question.value:
Predictor variables 
This study will derive measures of two predictor variables, white matter integrity and connectome integration, from the structural connectomes of the participants. Before calculation of these variables, we will apply a consistency thresholding method to the structural connectomes, to retain 30% of all connections. Then, as measures of white matter integrity, the general mean diffusivity (gMD) and general fractional anisotropy (gFA) will be extracted from the MD and FA weighted connectomes. Second, global efficiency will be calculated from both of the weighted connectomes as measures of connectome integration. The exact calculation of global efficiency can be found in Rubinov & Sporns (2010).

Mediating variables 
The two mediating variables in this study will be processing speed and general cognitive ability (g). Processing speed will be measured as the mean time to correctly identify matches in the UKB reaction time task. General cognitive ability will be calculated as the general factor of the scores on the UKB pairs memory, UKB reaction time, UKB prospective memory, UKB fluid intelligence and UKB numeric memory. The exact data fields and respective links to the UK biobank data showcase for these variables are provided in the supplementary materials, table 1. 

Outcome variables 
This study will look at two outcome variables. For research question 1, the outcome variable will be whether participants indicated to have ever had a PLE. This variable is thus dichotomous, with two categories: ever had a PLE and never had a PLE. For research question 2, the outcome variable will be whether participants reported to have had a specific PLE. This variable is categorical, with 5 categories: Ever had an auditory hallucination, ever had a visual hallucination, ever had a persecutory delusion, ever had a delusion of reference and never had a psychotic-like experience. These variables were all derived from answers on the UKB mental health questionnaire. The exact data fields and respective links to the UK biobank data showcase for these variables are provided in the supplementary materials, table 1. More information on the exact questions of the mental health questionnaire can be found in the supplementary materials, table 2. 
Data from participants who indicate having had different kinds of PLE will be used in the categories of all the PLE they reported (e.g. if a participant indicated to have had a visual hallucination and an auditory hallucination, their data will be used in both these categories). Because of the low prevalence rate of each of the PLE, we will match participants with PLE and controls by age and sex with a 1:10 ratio, where the biggest group with PLE will be taken as a benchmark (for example, if the biggest PLE category is visual hallucinations with 200 participants, the no PLE category will have 2000 participants).

Covariates
This study will include age at recruitment, sex and amount of distress as covariates in all analyses. Amount of distress will be measured through the question “How distressing did you find having any of these experiences?”. Answer possibilities where: “Prefer not to answer”, “Do not know”, “Not distressing at all, it was a positive experience”, “Not distressing, a neutral experience”, “A bit distressing”, “Quite distressing”, and “Very distressing”. We will recode all the informative (the last 5) answers from -1 (not distressing at all) to 3 (very distressing). The exact data fields and respective links to the UK biobank data showcase for these variables are provided in the supplementary materials, table 1. More information on the exact questions of the mental health questionnaire can be found in the supplementary materials, table 2.

Predictor variables
The general factor of FA and MD will be derived through principal component analyses. 

Mediating variables
A measure of general cognitive ability will be derived through a principal component analysis. The score for processing speed will be calculated as the mean time to correctly identify matches on 12 trials of the UKB reaction time task

PCA for general cognitive ability 
To create a score for general cognitive ability the test scores on UKB pairs memory, UKB reaction time, UKB prospective memory, UKB fluid intelligence and UKB numeric memory will be entered in a PCA. Before entering the scores into the PCA, the normality of the distribution of the scores will be checked. If scores aren’t normally distributed, necessary transformations will be performed. Based on previous studies that looked at deriving a measure of general cognitive ability from the scores on these reaction tasks ((Fawns-Ritchie & Deary, 2019; Lyall et al., 2016) we expect the all the scores to correlate with a low to medium effect size. We also expect that a single principal component will emerge from the PCA, accounting for about 40% of the variance We will therefore save the first unrotated component of this PCA as a measure of general cognitive ability. 

PCA for gFA and gMD
To obtain the general FA and MD measures, we will perform PCA on the FA and MD scores of all the connections left after thresholding of the FA and MD weighted connectomes. Before entering the scores into the PCA, the normality of the distribution of the scores will be checked. If scores aren’t normally distributed, necessary transformations will be performed. Based on a study by Alloza et al. (2016) that also calculated a general FA and MD trough PCA, we expect one principal component to emerge for both FA and MD. We expect the principal component for FA to explain approximately 45% of the variance and the principal component for MD to explain about 55% of the variance. Therefore, the first unrotated principal component will be saved as a measure of either general FA or general MD.

Research question 1
Hypotheses belonging to research question one will be tested with mediation analyses through SEM. Models will be constructed using the Lavaan package in R, using the full information maximum likelihood estimation to account for missing data. We will construct 4 mediation models, alternating between general FA, general MD and global efficiency from a MD and FA weighed connectome as independent variables. 
	Regression slopes will be estimated through SEM using linear and logistic regression. Based on Rijnhart, Twisk, Eekhout, & Heymans (2019), we won’t standardize the regression coefficients. We expect significant regression slopes between all measures of the independent variables (gFA,gMD, global efficiency) and the dependent variable (having PLE). We also expect significant slopes between the independent variables and mediating variables, and significant slopes on a logistic regression for the mediating variables and the dependent variable. Furthermore, we expect that the bootstrapped 95% confidence intervals of the indirect effects (a*b and d*e) and the proportion mediated (ab /(ab +c) and de/(de +a) ) does not contain zero (i.e. the indirect effects are significant). Assumptions of multivariate normality and homoscedasticity will be checked for the linear regressions. When violated, non-linear transformations or corrections will be performed. False discovery rate (FDR) corrections will be applied to correct for multiple testing. The exact model that will be entered in SEM is pictured in figure 1. As mentioned before, age, sex and amount of distress will be entered as covariates in these analyses. 

Research Question 2 
To test the hypotheses of research question two, we will perform logistic regressions with mean FA and mean MD per ROI-ROI connection of the thresholded connectomes as independent variables, and category as dependent variable. This will result in a multitude of regression coefficients relating white matter integrity in ROI-ROI connections to PLE. To test our hypotheses that integrity in specific white matter tracts is altered for specific PLE, we will perform the Williams test for the comparison of regression slope magnitudes on the hypothesized tracts (Williams, 1959). We expect that the hypothesized tracts be significantly more strongly correlated with our dependent variable than the other connections. Again, all analyses will be corrected for multiple testing using FDR correction.

q18.value: If any of the predicting or mediating variables are not normally distributed, we will apply the necessary transformations to approximate normality.

q19.value:
Research Question 1 
To make inferences about the significance of the slopes (beta’s) of the separate regression analyses, we will use the standard p <0.05 criteria. All p-values will be corrected with FDR. To make inferences about the hypothesized mediations, we will use the bootstrapped 95% confidence intervals of the indirect effects (a*b and d*e) and the proportion mediated (ab /(ab +c) and de/(de +a). We will consider confidence intervals that do not contain zero to be supportive of the hypotheses. 

Research Question 2 
To make inferences about the significance of the slopes (beta’s) of the separate logistic regressions and the Williams tests, we will use the standard p <0.05 criteria. All p-values will be corrected for multiple testing using FDR correction.

q20.value: Participants who scored 3.5 SD above or below the group average on the mediating or independent variables will be excluded from analyses. Participants who answered “Prefer not to answer” or “Do not know” to the question whether the PLE where considered distressing will also be excluded from our analyses.

q21.value: We will perform SEM with the full information maximum likelihood estimation to account for missing data.

q22.value: We will also perform all above mentioned analyses with people with schizophrenia included. Furthermore, we will investigate the influence of distress on all the above mentioned analyses. Distress will be included as covariates in all analyses. If it proves to be a significant covariate, we will also run all above mentioned analyses only on people who reported experiencing distress associated with PLE.

q23.value:
Details on connectome construction 
T1 weighted and diffusion MRI images were acquired using a Siemens Skyra 3T scanner. A detailed description on the image acquisition can be found on the UK biobank website (http://biobank.ctsu.ox.ac.uk/crystal/refer.cgi?id=1977 and http://biobank.ctsu.ox.ac.uk /crystal/refer.cgi?id=2367).  Information on pre-processing and quality control is available in Alfaro-Almagro et al. (2017). To construct the connectomes, each T1 weighted image was segmented into 85 regions of interest (ROI). Cortical regions were consequently identified using the Desikan-Killiany atlas (Desikan et al., 2006), resulting in 34 cortical structures per hemisphere. Eight subcortical grey matter structures were also identified based on Fischl et al. (2002). A list of all ROI’s can be found in the appendix. Subsequently, whole-brain probabilistic tractography was performed and weighted connectomes were constructed by identifying all connections between ROI’s. The network weightings were computed for FA and MD. These connections per network weighting were recorded in an 85 x 85 connectivity matrix. Further information on the construction of the connectomes can be found in Buchanan et al. (2020).

References 

Alfaro-Almagro, F., Jenkinson, M., Bangerter, N. K., Andersson, J. L., Griffanti, L., Douaud, G., ... & Vidaurre, D. (2018). Image processing and Quality Control for the first 10,000 brain imaging datasets from UK Biobank. Neuroimage, 166, 400-424.

Alloza, C., Cox, S. R., Duff, B., Semple, S. I., Bastin, M. E., Whalley, H. C., & Lawrie, S. M. (2016). Information processing speed mediates the relationship between white matter and general intelligence in schizophrenia. Psychiatry Research - Neuroimaging, 254, 26–33.

Buchanan, C. R., Bastin, M. E., Ritchie, S. J., Liewald, D. C., Madole, J. W., Tucker-Drob, E. M., … Cox, S. R. (2020). The effect of network thresholding and weighting on structural brain networks in the UK Biobank. NeuroImage, 211. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuroimage.2019.116443

Desikan, R. S., Ségonne, F., Fischl, B., Quinn, B. T., Dickerson, B. C., Blacker, D., ... & Albert, M. S. (2006). An automated labeling system for subdividing the human cerebral cortex on MRI scans into gyral based regions of interest. Neuroimage, 31(3), 968-980.

Fawns-Ritchie, C., & Deary, I. J. (2019). Reliability and validity of the UK Biobank cognitive tests. MedRxiv, 19002204. https://doi.org/10.1101/19002204

Fischl, B., Salat, D. H., Busa, E., Albert, M., Dieterich, M., Haselgrove, C., ... & Montillo, A. (2002). Whole brain segmentation: automated labeling of neuroanatomical structures in the human brain. Neuron, 33(3), 341-355.

Lyall, D. M., Cullen, B., Allerhand, M., Smith, D. J., Mackay, D., Evans, J., … Pell, J. P. (2016). Cognitive Test Scores in UK Biobank: Data Reduction in 480,416 Participants and Longitudinal Stability in 20,346 Participants. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0154222

Rijnhart, J. J., Twisk, J. W., Eekhout, I., & Heymans, M. W. (2019). Comparison of logistic-	regression based methods for simple mediation analysis with a dichotomous outcome variable. BMC medical research methodology, 19(1), 19.

Rubinov, M., & Sporns, O. (2010). Complex network measures of brain connectivity: Uses and interpretations. NeuroImage, 52(3), 1059–1069. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuroimage.2009.10.003

Williams, E. J. (1959). The comparison of regression variables. Journal of the Royal Statistical 	Society: Series B (Methodological), 21(2), 396-399.

Research Question 2 
To test the hypotheses of research question two, we will perform logistic regressions with mean FA and mean MD per ROI-ROI connection of the thresholded connectomes as independent variables, and category as dependent variable. This will result in a multitude of regression coefficients relating white matter integrity in ROI-ROI connections to PLE. To test our hypotheses that integrity in specific white matter tracts is altered for specific PLE, we will perform the Williams test for the comparison of regression slope magnitudes on the hypothesized tracts (Williams, 1959). We expect that the hypothesized tracts be significantly more strongly correlated with our dependent variable than the other connections. Again, all analyses will be corrected for multiple testing using FDR correction.

attributes.title: Characteristics of scientific articles on COVID-19 published during the initial three months of the pandemic: protocol for a meta-epidemiological study
attributes.description:
This manuscript presents a protocol for a meta-epidemiological study on the characteristics of scientific articles on COVID-19 published during the initial three months of the pandemic.

TITLE
Characteristics of scientific articles on COVID-19 published during the initial three months of the pandemic: protocol for a meta-epidemiological study

AUTHORS
Nicola Di Girolamo and Reint Meursinge Reynders

ORCID NUMBERS
Nicola Di Girolamo ORCID: 0000-0001-5203-9765
Reint Meursinge Reynders ORCID: 0000-0002-2233-9748

AFFILIATIONS AUTHORS
Nicola Di Girolamo 1,2 (Associate professor and editor)
1 Center for veterinary health sciences, Oklahoma State University, 2065 W. Farm Road, Stillwater, Oklahoma 74078, USA.
2 EBMVet, Via Sigismondo Trecchi 20, Cremona CR 26100, Italy. 
Email: nicoladiggi@gmail.com

Reint Meursinge Reynders 3,4 (Senior scientist and associate editor)
3 Department of oral and maxillofacial surgery, Amsterdam University Medical Center, University of Amsterdam, Meibergdreef 9, 1105 AZ Amsterdam, The 
Netherlands.  
4 Private practice of orthodontics, Via Matteo Bandello 15, 20123 Milan, Italy. 
Email: reyndersmail@gmail.com

CORRESPONDING AUTHOR
Nicola Di Girolamo1,2 (Associate professor and editor)
1 Center for veterinary health sciences, Oklahoma State University, 2065 W. Farm Road, Stillwater, Oklahoma 74078, USA.
2 EBMVet, Via Sigismondo Trecchi 20, Cremona CR 26100, Italy. 
Email: nicoladiggi@gmail.com

ABSTRACT
Objectives:  
(1) What is the prevalence of primary and secondary articles on COVID-19 in the first 3 months of the pandemic?
(2) What are the characteristics of both primary and secondary articles on COVID-19?
(3) How does the COVID-19 publishing pattern compare with the publishing pattern of the last pandemic, i.e., Swine Flu pandemic?

Design: 
Meta-epidemiological cross-sectional study

Study sample: 
All research articles on Covid-19 indexed in PubMed (Medline) up to 2 April 2020.

Main outcome measures: 
Predominantly prevalence statistics

KEYWORDS
Covid-19; Coronavirus; SARS-nCoV-2; Swine Flu; H1N1 strain; study design; research quality; healthcare policy; evidence-based medicine

INTRODUCTION
The outbreak of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic has led to prolific publishing on this health issue. Here, we will assess the scientific literature to analyze the characteristics of articles published on COVID-19 during the first 3 months of this pandemic. We will assess the type, quantity, and quality of this literature to get an insight in the available knowledge base for controlling this pandemic early on. We will divide the literature in primary and secondary articles. Primary articles refer to original research studies that create new or confirming data on a problem, e.g. an health issue. Secondary articles use these data to assess the current knowledge status on this problem. We will also compare the publishing pattern during the first 3 months of the COVID-19 pandemic with this pattern during the most recent pandemic, i.e., the H1N1 pandemic.

OBJECTIVES
Our main objectives are summarized in the following 3 research questions: 
(1) What is the prevalence of primary and secondary articles on COVID-19 in the first 3 months of the pandemic?
(2) What are the characteristics of both primary and secondary articles?
(3) How does the publishing pattern during the first 3 months of the COVID-19 pandemic compare with the publishing pattern of the last pandemic, i.e., Swine Flu pandemic?

METHODS
Type of study
We will conduct a cross-sectional (meta-epidemiological) study.

Reporting of the study
We will use Strengthening the Reporting of Observational Studies in Epidemiology (STROBE) Statement as the framework for reporting this study (von Elm 2007). We will report our methods for the Swine Flu sample at the end of the methods section. 

Eligibility criteria
Any type of article published on COVID-19 will be eligible. This implies that a broad spectrum of articles ranging from letters to the editors to randomized controlled trials will be included. No eligibility criteria will be applied to specific participants, interventions, comparators, outcomes, endpoints, or settings of the articles. Articles that did not present an abstract as well as abstracts that were not reported  in English will be excluded.

Information sources and search strategy
We will search eligible articles on COVID-19  in PubMed (MEDLINE) till April 2 2020. Our search strategy for PubMed (MEDLINE) is presented in Table 1 and will be prepared for the eligible search dates. We will use the search string “(COVID-19 OR COVID)” and apply the filter ‘Abstract’.

Table 1. Search strategy for COVID-19
Search: COVID-19 OR COVID Filters: Abstract
((((((("covid 19"[All Fields] OR "covid 2019"[All Fields]) OR "severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2"[Supplementary Concept]) OR "severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2"[All Fields]) OR "2019 ncov"[All Fields]) OR "sars cov 2"[All Fields]) OR "2019ncov"[All Fields]) OR (("wuhan"[All Fields] AND ("coronavirus"[MeSH Terms] OR "coronavirus"[All Fields])) AND (2019/12/1:2019/12/31[Date - Publication] OR 2020/1/1:2020/12/31[Date - Publication]))) OR "COVID"[All Fields]
Translations
COVID-19: "COVID-19"[All Fields] OR "COVID-2019"[All Fields] OR "severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2"[Supplementary Concept] OR "severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2"[All Fields] OR "2019-nCoV"[All Fields] OR "SARS-CoV-2"[All Fields] OR "2019nCoV"[All Fields] OR (("Wuhan"[All Fields] AND ("coronavirus"[MeSH Terms] OR "coronavirus"[All Fields])) AND (2019/12[PDAT] OR 2020[PDAT]))

Selection of articles and data extraction
Two operators (Nicola di Girolamo and Reint Meursinge Reynders) will conduct the selection of articles and the data extraction procedures independently. These operators pilot tested these methods on 40 articles to calibrate operators and to fine-tune research methods, e.g., the data extraction forms (Table 2). Disagreements during the selection of articles and data extraction procedures will be resolved through discussions between these operators. A methodologist will be consulted in the case of persisting disagreements. We will report the flow of our selection of articles and will include our raw data with the final research study.

Table 2. Data extraction forms
Title: Report the title of the article
PMID: Report  the PubMed-Indexed for MEDLINE (PMID)
Authors:	Report the authors of the article
Citation:	Report the citations of the article
First author: Report the first author of the article
Journal/Book: Report the name of the journal or book
Publication year: Report the year of publication of the article
Creation date: Report the date of the creation of the Digital Object Identifier (DOI) 
DOI:	 Report the DOI 
DOI LINK: Report the link to the DOI
Language of full text: Report the language in which the full text of the article was published
Language if not English: Report the language of the full text if not English
Country: Report the country of the first institution of the first author
Type of study: Report the type of study, e.g., human medical research/in vitro/in silico/review/guidelines etc.
Study design: Report the study design. Only the design of human medical research studies will be reported
Sample size: Report the sample size. Only the sample size of human medical research studies will be reported
Objectives: Report whether the objectives of the article were reported in the abstract. Possible answers: Yes/No
Limitations/problems reported in the abstract: Report whether limitations/or problems of the article were reported in the abstract. Possible answers: Yes/No
Additional comments: Report possible additional comments
Conclusions: Copy and paste the conclusions reported in the abstract

Classification of the included articles
We will classify each included article as either a primary or a secondary article. Primary articles cover original research studies and secondary articles cover perspectives and syntheses of the available knowledge on COVID-19 such as, viewpoints, commentaries, guidelines, reviews etc. Primary articles will be divided in 5 groups, i.e., human medical research, in silico, in vitro, animal research, and surveys or studies on health professionals. These groups will be further subdivided according to the pertinent research designs.
Our classification of articles will not be exclusively based on the labels assigned by the authors of the articles, because of the potential risk of  mislabeling (Esene 2014). We will weigh the author’ labels before assigning our final classification. 

Abstract assessment
We will screen the abstracts to assess whether objectives and limitations of the article were reported or not. Limitations will be subdivided in methodological and general limitations. The former refers to reporting of at least one methodological limitation in the abstract. General limitations refer to reporting some sort of limitation not inherent to the design of the paper, e.g., further research on this topic is needed etc. 

Information sources and search strategy for the Swine Flu sample
We will search PubMed (MEDLINE) for eligible articles on H1N1 during the first 3 months of the Swine Flu outbreak (04/25/09-7/25/09). Our search strategy for PubMed (MEDLINE) is presented in Table 3. We will use the search string “((H1N1) OR "swine influenza")” and apply the filter ‘Abstract’. This search strategy will be prepared for the eligible search dates.

Table 3. Search strategy for H1N1
Search: (H1N1) OR (swine influenza) Filters: Abstract
"H1N1"[All Fields] OR (((("orthomyxoviridae infections"[MeSH Terms] OR ("orthomyxoviridae"[All Fields] AND "infections"[All Fields])) OR "orthomyxoviridae infections"[All Fields]) OR ("swine"[All Fields] AND "influenza"[All Fields])) OR "swine influenza"[All Fields])
Translations
swine influenza: "orthomyxoviridae infections"[MeSH Terms] OR ("orthomyxoviridae"[All Fields] AND "infections"[All Fields]) OR "orthomyxoviridae infections"[All Fields] OR ("swine"[All Fields] AND "influenza"[All Fields]) OR "swine influenza"[All Fields]

Selection of articles, data extraction, and classification of the included articles for the Swine Flu sample
For the selection of articles, data extraction, and the classification of the included articles for the Swine Flu sample we will adopt the methods presented for the COVID-19 sample. We will report on the classification of primary and secondary articles in this sample. 

Data analysis
We will use descriptive statistics expressed as medians with interquartile ranges (IQR) and ranges or absolute counts and percentages. Multivariate logistic regression models will be developed to explore factors associated with the primary outcomes and to provide odds ratio adjusted for confounders (Peng & So, 2002; Heck, Thomas & Tabata, 2013). Variables will be retained in the models regardless of their statistical significance. Goodness of fit will be assessed with Hosmer-Lemshow test and Nagelkerke R squared. Data analyses and figures will be done with SPSS (version 24, IBM) and R 3.6.3 (R Core Team, 2020, www.R-project.org/). 

Outcomes
Table 4 summarizes our planned outcomes. For most of these outcomes we will calculate prevalence statistics. We did not involve patients or other stakeholders in developing our research questions or outcomes.

Table 4. Summary of planned outcomes
Published papers on COVID-19
Primary and secondary articles on COVID-19
Type of primary articles on COVID-19
Research design of primary articles on COVID-19
Type of secondary articles on COVID-19
Articles on COVID-19 per country
Journals on COVID-19
Reporting of objectives in the abstract in included articles on COVID-19
Reporting of limitations in the abstract in included articles on COVID-19
Published papers on H1N1
Primary and secondary articles on H1N1
Type of primary articles on H1N1
Research design of primary articles on H1N1
Type of secondary articles on H1N1
Differences in publishing trends between COVID-19 and H1N1

Differences between the protocol and the final study
Originally we also planned to extract whether included studies were part of multi center projects. After the completion of our pilot tests we decided not to extract these data, because they could not be extracted reliably. This manuscript represents the latest version of our protocol, i.e., the protocol after the completion of our pilot tests. All differences between this protocol and the methods used in the study will be reported in the final manuscript of the study with rationale.

REFERENCES
Esene 2014
Esene IN, Ngu J, El Zoghby M, et al. Case series and descriptive cohort studies in neurosurgery: the confusion and solution. Childs Nerv Syst. 2014;30(8):1321–1332. doi:10.1007/s00381-014-2460-1.

Von Elm 2007
von Elm E, Altman DG, Egger M, Pocock SJ, Gøtzsche PC, Vandenbroucke JP; STROBE Initiative. The Strengthening the Reporting of Observational Studies in Epidemiology (STROBE) statement: guidelines for reporting observational studies. Ann Intern Med. 2007 Oct 16;147(8):573-7.

attributes.title: Perceptions and projections of COVID-19
attributes.description: In this research we aim to investigate how people remember the initial phase of the COVID-19 crisis, how they perceive it in the present, and how they imagine it will progress in the future. We are planning to conduct a longitudinal study to track how people's projections and memories change as time pass.

q2.value:
This research is mostly exploratory. We do not have specific hypotheses for most of the questions. 

We only have a certain hypothesis about the relation between agency and future predictions. In our previous research (Topcu & Hirst, 2020) we found that when people attribute more agency to themselves and their nation they become more optimistic about the future. If that holds true for this pandemic, we expect that participants would make a more optimistic prediction about the pandemic -e.g. they will predict fewer cases/deaths in the future- if they think themselves or their nation have agency in controlling the spread of the virus.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Within subjects design with 1 main factor: Time orientation with three levels: Past (6 weeks ago), Present, Future (6 weeks from now) 

Since this will be a longitudinal study we will also compare variables across time. Right now we are planning to collect data in 2 time points: Now and In 6 weeks. We might collect additional data if needed.

q7.value: The questions will be presented in a blocked fashion. The main blocks are: Past, Present, and Future. The order of presenting these blocks is randomized. Within each time-block there will be other blocks that included different categories of questions (e.g. communication, agency etc.). These order of these blocks will also be randomized.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
This study will be web-based. We will use the Amazon Mechanical Turk platform to collect data, and Qualtrics to design the survey. We have 2 main inclusion criteria: to be at least 18 years of age and to be a US citizen.
Since this is online study we will have 5 attention checks throughout the study. Participants who fail in more than 2 attention checks will be excluded from the sample.

q11.value: We are planning to collect data from 275 participants.

q12.value:
In our previous research (Topcu & Hirst, 2020) we found that the difference score between future and past responses for group agency predicts the difference score for the valence score. In the multiple linear regression model our predictors were self and group agency. 

In this new research we don't have the exact same variables. But there are similar variables involved. We predict that the agency people attribute to themselves, their nation, the US government, and their state’s government in controlling the spread of the Coronavirus might predict their optimism about future estimations of the spread. So in determining our sample size we used the correlation coefficients between self & group-agency difference with valence difference, from our previous research. The effect size (F2) was 0.22, and the power was 0.95. In this research we have 2 more predictors, therefore the number of predictors was set at 4. The total sample size needed in this model was 89. 

We are planning to collect data for at least 1 more time point in the future. Considering the drop-out rates and the people who will fail attention checks we decided a priori to collect data from 285 participants.

question.value: N/A

There are 3 main sections in the study: past (6 weeks ago), present, and future (6 weeks from now). Most of the questions are adapted to fit these 3 sections. 

The question categories that repeat in each section are the following:
1. Vividness of memory/imagination (Vividness, Detailedness)
2. Emotional reactions (scared, worried, indifferent)
3. Preparedness, Agency, Efficacy in controlling the spread of Coronavirus (for Self, State, US government, America as a nation)
4. Communication & media use about coronavirus (how much they follow the news, how much they communicate etc.)
5. Factual predictions (estimations about the number of people who are tested positive, who are infected, and who died for the world, the US, and the state they live in)

Extra questions in the "present section": Precautions and social distancing (how much they go out, how many people they see, how frequently they wash hands etc.)

Question categories in addition to these 3 sections
1. Knowledge of past epidemics/pandemics. A list of major epidemics/pandemics is given. For each they rate how much they know about and how severe they think it was compared to Coronavirus. Also they evaluate the extent to which they think Coronavirus is like influence vs SARS.
2. End of Pandemic. Estimations about when they think the pandemic will end. Evaluations about the agents involved in ending the pandemic. Estimations about the number of people who will be infected/die when the pandemic ends around the world, in the US, and in their state. 
3. Control questions. Questions about whether themselves or someone they know got infected of Coronavirus etc. 
4. Demographics

As mentioned before, this research is mainly an exploratory research with variables that were not used before. 

We have one main hypothesis: We predict perceived agency to predict increased optimism for the spread of Coronavirus in the future. We will test this prediction using a multiple linear regression. Our predictor variables will be self-agency, group-agency (attributed to American people), agency of the US government, and agency of the state. The outcome variables will be the estimated number of people who will be infected and who will die in the United States and in one's state.

q20.value: We will have 5 attention checks throughout our survey. We will exclude participants who fail in more than 2 attention checks.

attributes.title: Study 1: SDO, Belief and Science, and Speciesism: the moderated role of gender

q1.value: Study 1: SDO, Belief and Science, and Speciesism: the moderated role of gender (erratum)

q3.value:
As you will probably notice, the first preregistration on the project page (https://osf.io/n27zj) is mentioning in the title, variables that are not presented in the preregistration. In fact, this preregistration is a copy/paste of another preregistration from another project (https://osf.io/ythv5) and the real preregistration has not been loaded. You will find below the real preregistration, I'm using the OSF template to link to this preregistration the original preregistration that were done using the AsPredicted template and on MSword.

This study is a part of a larger data collection where we decided to split our data set into two equal parts to investigate two different questions.
In this first study we are interested in the linked between four variables: the SDO, the Belief in Science and the Speciesism and the moderating effect of gender.
In the second study (that you will find here: https://osf.io/jdzuf/ and to which the other preregistration of this page refers) we are interested on the effect of the Speciesism on the both perception of emotions and suffering among animals and the mediating role of the Empathy.

q4.value:
This project is a correlational study where we will investigate how certain variables may interact together and compose a model
In this study, we will first investigate the link between Social Dominance Orientation (SDO), Speciesism (S) and Belief in Science (BS) and we first expect a positive link among these three variables.
Considering that males tend to have greater SDO-levels than females, have stronger attitudes against animal concern (i.e., less vegetarian), and have lower empathy-level, we are also expecting to find a moderator effect of the gender of participant on each of these three links (SDO-BS, SDO-S; S-BS). We presume that being a male would accentuate the links between our variables of interest when being a woman would attenuate these links.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: You will find attached the original AsPredicted preregistration

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Regarding an experimental study, we made a large data collection but we regarding some a-priori defined (such as fro example psychology/biology/medicine/chemistry... students), we excluded a lot of participants. We thus decided to perform two correlational studies with these data.

question.value:
Participants were recruited using Facebook promotions, press and flyers and the data collection lasted 1 year and half. As explained before, the data collection was originally for another purpose, a first online questionnaire before an experimental task in a lab.

In this study, participants are only participants who were excluded for the experimental task or participants who did not show up for the second experimental task.
NA

-Social Dominance Orientation (Sidanius & Pratto): 8 items, validated scale, french translation, 5 points likert scale

-Speciesism (Caviola, et al., 2018): 6 items, validated scale, french translation, 5 points likert scale

-Belief in Science: 4 items, developed in our lab and has a great internal consistency regarding previous results on other studies, 5 points likert scale

-Sexe: Male/Female

First, we will assess if our variables of interest are well related to each other, we will perform a set of different Bravais Pearson correlational analysis between:
-SDO and S
-S and BS
-S and SDO

Then, performing regression analysis we will investigate for our three links (SDO-S; S-BS; BS-SDO) if we can find an interaction effect of the gender.

q22.value:
Upstream Cleaning-data:
- As the survey was done on internet and mainly diffused via a Facebook promotion post, we will use an item "please copy your given confidential code in the blank space below" as a way to remove bots (using this question as a captcha). 
- We will also remove every participants who did not complete the questionnaire while excluding every participants who did not complete the last item
- We will also use the previous point as an attention check and remove participants who did not correctly report their codes. It will also allow us to remove all the tests who were made by experimenters, testing if the questionnaire was well working (instruction was always done to never report the presented confidentiality code during a test).
- As this questionnaire is a part of another project (more details in the procedure of the OSF page), in order to not analyze two times the same data we will also exclude upstream data from participants that are already been selected for the other project.

Specific exclusion regarding the study:
- We will apply an interpolation procedure to deal with missing values if less that 25 % of a scale has missing values. If a scale has more than 25% missing values, the participant will be discarded on that measure (i.e., SDO, S, BS)

q25.value:
More variables were presented on the questionnaire because of the original purpose of this survey (i.e., a later experimental task), but in this study we will only look at our 4 chosen variables (i.e., S, SDO, BS, gender) and some of the others will be analyzed in the second project.

This study is a part of a larger data-collection and we decided to compose two independent studies with each half of the data collected. 
This study is independent from the other but to see the other study, please refer to this link: https://osf.io/jdzuf/
Data were collected and cleaned (remove of bots, remove of participants/experimenters who failed the "attention task" and remove of participants who already did the experimental lab task) but no analyses regarding any variables were performed.

We extracted data from a questionnaire, which is still running, and continue to collect data and we are planning to continue to collect data until summer 2021 and we may make a second study, investigating or not the same ideas (following the results of this study or not).

registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q11: Regarding an experimental study, we made a large data collection but we regarding some a-priori defined (such as fro example psychology/biology/medicine/chemistry... students), we excluded a lot of participants. We thus decided to perform two correlational studies with these data.
registration_responses.q22:
Upstream Cleaning-data:
- As the survey was done on internet and mainly diffused via a Facebook promotion post, we will use an item "please copy your given confidential code in the blank space below" as a way to remove bots (using this question as a captcha). 
- We will also remove every participants who did not complete the questionnaire while excluding every participants who did not complete the last item
- We will also use the previous point as an attention check and remove participants who did not correctly report their codes. It will also allow us to remove all the tests who were made by experimenters, testing if the questionnaire was well working (instruction was always done to never report the presented confidentiality code during a test).
- As this questionnaire is a part of another project (more details in the procedure of the OSF page), in order to not analyze two times the same data we will also exclude upstream data from participants that are already been selected for the other project.

Specific exclusion regarding the study:
- We will apply an interpolation procedure to deal with missing values if less that 25 % of a scale has missing values. If a scale has more than 25% missing values, the participant will be discarded on that measure (i.e., SDO, S, BS)
registration_responses.q25:
More variables were presented on the questionnaire because of the original purpose of this survey (i.e., a later experimental task), but in this study we will only look at our 4 chosen variables (i.e., S, SDO, BS, gender) and some of the others will be analyzed in the second project.

This study is a part of a larger data-collection and we decided to compose two independent studies with each half of the data collected. 
This study is independent from the other but to see the other study, please refer to this link: https://osf.io/jdzuf/
Data were collected and cleaned (remove of bots, remove of participants/experimenters who failed the "attention task" and remove of participants who already did the experimental lab task) but no analyses regarding any variables were performed.

We extracted data from a questionnaire, which is still running, and continue to collect data and we are planning to continue to collect data until summer 2021 and we may make a second study, investigating or not the same ideas (following the results of this study or not).
registration_responses.q8.question: You will find attached the original AsPredicted preregistration
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants were recruited using Facebook promotions, press and flyers and the data collection lasted 1 year and half. As explained before, the data collection was originally for another purpose, a first online questionnaire before an experimental task in a lab.

In this study, participants are only participants who were excluded for the experimental task or participants who did not show up for the second experimental task.

attributes.title: Social isolation and vocabulary development: insights from British families with varying SES
attributes.description: A convincing body of research has shown that shared book reading in early childhood promotes language development (O'Farrelly et al., 2018; Sénéchal and Young, 2008). Yet, families with low social economic status (SES) might provide less stimulating environment for language development to their children, as compared to families with high SES, as they have sparser access to books and engage less frequently in shared reading interactions (Kelly et al., 2011, Melhuish et al., 2008). For instance, it has been estimated, that by the age of 4 years, toddlers from low SES families have heard about 30 million less words than peers from higher SES families (Hart and Risley, 1995). The current longitudinal study aims to assess home activities and interactions that parents engage in with their 8 to 36-month-old infants during the period of coronavirus lockdown in the UK, and to examine their role in early vocabulary development of British infants across families varying in SES-background. This is part of a collaborative multilab project, based on the initiative of the Department of Psychology at the University of Oslo.

q2.value:
We expect that parents from lower SES backgrounds will engage less frequently in shared book reading activities and structured parent-infant interactions than parents from higher SES backgrounds. 

We hypothesise that infants in lower SES families might be exposed to TV/cartoons more than infants in higher SES families.

We expect that infants growing up in lower SES families will have smaller gains in both receptive and expressive vocabulary sizes than infants growing up in higher SES families. 

We expect that the frequency of shared book reading will explain more variance in vocabulary size than the frequency of other child-parent activities (see Montag et al., 2015). 

We predict that more frequent use of dialogue style in shared book reading will be related to larger gains in expressive vocabulary (Flack et al., 2015). 

We expect that more frequent exposure to TV/baby cartoons will be related to smaller gains in receptive vocabulary (cf Kuhl et al., 2003).

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study has a regression design: we will examine whether family's SES, frequency of shared book reading, structured plays and TV/baby cartoons exposure modulate gains in receptive and expressive vocabulary sizes for monolingual and bilingual toddlers.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Parents/guardians of 8-to-36-month-old infants from the researcher's pool of contacts will be invited to participate in this study. We will also contact parents through social media (i.e. Facebook and Twitter). Parents will be asked to complete a questionnaire at the beginning of the school and nursery closure period (Time 1) and again, once social distancing rules cease and the schools and nurseries reopen (Time 2). The questionnaires at Time 1 will include a vocabulary questionnaire (the Oxford Communicative Development Inventory O-CDI; Hamilton, Plunkett, & Schafer, 2000), a family background questionnaire (which will include information about siblings' gender and age, and family's SES), the Early Parenting Attitudes Questionnaire (Hembacher & Frank, 2018), four questions about use of infant directed speech, and a measure of smartphone use. At Time 2, we will repeat the O-CDI, screen time measure, and ask what type of activities parents engaged in with their child (and activity frequency) during the isolation period. The O-CDI will provide us with an estimate of a child's comprehensive and productive vocabulary size in each language at Time 1 and Time 2. Children who were born more than two weeks before term and children with auditory or visual deficits will be excluded from analyses.

q11.value: We will stop data collection after completion of questionnaires at Time 2 (i.e. as soon as the social distancing rules cease and the schools and nurseries are reopened in the UK). We will aim to invite as many participants as possible.

question.value:
Our dependent variable is the total number of words that parents reported that their child understands (between 8 and 18 months of age) and produces (between 8 and 36 months of age) in each of their languages. 

Our predictors are: the frequency of shared book reading during the social isolation period; the frequency of structured child-parent interactions; the amount of exposure to TV/cartoons. If the sample size permits, for those infants whose parents engage in shared book reading, we will include the type of reading as a factor (more verbalisations and dialogue-type of reading should result in larger gains in vocabulary). 

Maternal education (varying from 1 - Primary school to 8 - PhD) will be used as a proxy of SES and will be included as a predictor in the analyses.

We will also count the number of days between T1 and T2 (Gap_days) and will include it as a co-variate in the analyses.

First, we will examine the number of participants and the distribution of the SES backgrounds across the 6 possible categories (coded as a continuous variable, varying from 0 - Primary School to 5 - PhD). If the distribution is not homogeneous and we have relatively few answers per category (less than 5), then we will recode the SES variable into a binary factor (low [from 0 to 2], and high [from 3 to 5]). 

Then, we will examine the role of different activities parents have engaged in during the quarantine period and the gain score in the vocabulary size. Modality (receptive vs expressive) will be included as a factor for 8-18-month-old infants and Child will be included as a random variable. We also will model a possible interaction between Frequency_read and Modality (cf Karras et al, 2005). 

We will also include Gap_days as a co-variate in the analyses, as we expect larger gains of more days have passed between Time 1 and Time 2. 

Gains ~ Frequency_read + Frequency_interaction + Frequency_TV + Frequency_outdoor + Maternal_educ + Modality + Modality:Frequency_read + Gap_days + (1|Child), data=8_18_mo_data 

If the model does not converge, then the interaction term will be removed from the model and the analyses will be performed for each modality separately. 

Second, we will perform similar analyses for the expressive vocabulary (modality will be removed). For this, we will merge data on expressive vocabulary from 8-18 and 19-36-months of age. 

Gains ~ Frequency_read + Frequency_interaction + Frequency_TV + Frequency_outdoor + Maternal_educ + Gap_days, data=8_36_mo_data 

For those infants whose parents do engage in shared book reading, we will examine the role of type of reading and frequency of reading in each data sample. 

Gains ~ Type_reading + Frequency_read + Maternal_educ + Gap_days 

In a separate series of analyses, we will examine differences in everyday activities across families from different SES backgrounds. If the data permits (see above), then correlation analyses will be performed between Maternal_educ (6 categories, coded as a continuous variable) and the frequency of different activities during the lockdown period; if not, then a binary factor of SES will be used and then all the data will be split in two (families with high and families with low SES).

q18.value: For each child, the vocabulary size in percentile at Time 1 will be subtracted from the vocabulary size at Time 2, separately for receptive and expressive modality. As a result, we will obtain two gain scores (one for receptive and one for expressive vocabulary) for 8 to 18 month-old infants and one gain score for 19 to 36-month-old infants. The gain scores will be used in the statistical analyses. If we observe that some infants have close-to-ceiling vocabulary size at Time 1, then we will standardise the vocabulary score at both times and a standardised measure of gains will be used in the analyses: (voc_std(T2)-voc_std(T1)).

q22.value: In the exploratory analyses, we will examine the role of outdoor activities (type and frequency) in children's well-being and self-regulation. In addition, we will examine whether there are differences between those infants who already attended a kindergarten before the coronavirus outbreak and those who did not.

attributes.title: Assortative mating, autistic traits, empathizing-systemizing, and digit ratio (2D:4D)
attributes.description:
1. Background

Autism spectrum conditions are characterised by routine behaviours, narrow interests, and social and communicative difficulties (American Psychiatric Association, 2013).  There is a marked sex difference in autism diagnosis, with approximately four males being diagnosed per every one female (Fombonne, 2009), an effect that may (at least in part) be explainable in terms of atypical foetal sex hormone exposure (Auyeung et al., 2009; Baron-Cohen et al., 2015, 2019).  The prevalence of autism is approximately 1-2% (e.g. Baron-Cohen et al., 2009), which is a marked increase from Lotter's (1966) early estimate of 0.04%.  There are several reasons why prevalence might have increased, which include better recognition of autistic symptoms, growth of relevant services, and broadening of diagnostic criteria to include Asperger’s disorder and pervasive developmental disorder not otherwise specified (PDD-NOS).  However, it appears unlikely that these factors completely explain the effect.

With excellent attention to detail, and the ability to remain focussed on repetitive tasks, autistic people are often found to have an aptitude for working in the Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) industries (Baron-Cohen, Wheelwright, Skinner, Martin, & Clubley, 2001; Baron-Cohen, Wheelwright, Stott, Bolton, & Goodyer, 1997).  This effect also appears to extend to the broader autism phenotype (BAP), those people who display higher than average levels of autistic traits, but who do not themselves warrant a clinical diagnosis.  It has also been suggested that autism might be subject to positive assortative mating (i.e., people who measure highly in autistic traits may be more likely than chance to have children together; Baron-Cohen, 2006a, 2006b).  However, there is more than once process by which this could operate.  For instance, it could be that individuals with similar levels of autistic traits consciously or unconsciously seek each other out as romantic partners (active assortment) or that individuals with similar levels of autistic traits are more likely than chance to share other characteristics, such as a working environment, which lead to increased chances of a relationship starting (social homogamy) (see Kardum, Hudek-Knezevic, Schmitt, & Covic, 2017).  In addition, individuals may begin relationships with others who are more similar to themselves than expected by chance as regards autistic traits (initial assortment) or become more similar to their partner over the course of their relationship (convergence) (Kardum et al., 2017).

Evidence for the idea that autism is subject to assortative mating is provided by the observation that a person diagnosed with autism is 10-12 times more likely to marry or have a child with another autistic person than is someone without such a diagnosis (Nordsletten et al., 2016).  Furthermore, greater genetic similarity between the parents of autistic children than would be expected by chance has been reported (Connolly, Anney, Gallagher, & Heron, 2019), as have positive spousal correlations for a quantitative measure of autistic traits (Constantino & Todd, 2005).  Assortative mating may have important implications, and a greater recognition of such processes may help us understand geographical trends in autism prevalence.  This latter point is made clearer by the finding that rates of autism can sometimes cluster (Mazumdar, King, Liu, Zerubavel, & Bearman, 2010; van Meter et al., 2010), with children in Eindhoven (i.e. the ‘Silicon Valley of Europe’) being twice as likely to be autistic as children from two similar sized cities (Utrecht and Haarlem) in the Netherlands (Roelfsema et al., 2012).

The proposed research aims to increase our understanding of the processes that might underpin assortative mating in autism.  More specifically, we aim to determine whether autistic traits, empathizing, systemizing, and prenatal sex hormone exposure (as indexed by 2D:4D ratio) are correlated between heterosexual dating couples.


2. Method

2.1 A priori power analysis

We conducted an a priori power analysis using G*Power 3.1 (Faul, Erdfelder, Buchner, & Lang, 2009; Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007) to determine the sample size.  Assuming a medium effect size (r = 0.30) for intra-couple correlations on personality variables (e.g. Kardum et al., 2017) and 80% power, this analysis determined that a sample size of n=67 couples would be required to observe a statistically significant effect (p smaller than 0.05) with a one-tailed Pearson’s correlation test.

2.2 Apparatus/Materials

2.2.1 Demographics
Participants will report their sex, age, ethnicity, living status (i.e. whether or not living with their partner), length of relationship, marital status, educational level, student status, occupational status, and autism diagnostic status (see Appendix for wording of questions and response options).

2.2.2 Autistic traits and related measures
We will use the autism spectrum quotient (AQ; Baron-Cohen et al., 2001) to measure autistic traits, the Empathy Quotient (EQ; Baron-Cohen & Wheelwright, 2004) to measure empathizing, and the Systemizing Quotient-Revised (SQ-R; Wheelwright et al., 2006) to measure systemizing.  In addition, we will use the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test (Baron-Cohen, Wheelwright, Hill, Raste, & Plumb, 2001) and the Embedded Figures Test (Witkin, Oltman, Raskin, & Karp, 1971), as behavioural tasks that tap into abilities prerequisite to empathizing and systemizing, respectively.

2.2.3 Digit Ratio (2D:4D)
Prenatal testosterone exposure will be estimated via the proxy measure of digit ratio (2D:4D), i.e. the ratio of length between the second (index) and fourth (ring) fingers (see Manning et al., 1998; Manning, 2008).  The second and fourth fingers will be measured directly from participants’ hands by Research Assistants and MSc students using digital Vernier callipers (see Manning, 2008).  Two sets of measurements will be taken in the following order: R2D, R4D, L2D, L4D.  These will then be used to calculate two sets of R2D:4D (R2D:4D1 and R2D:4D2) and L2D:4D (L2D:4D1 and L2D:4D2) measurements.  Assuming that the intraclass-correlation coefficients (ICC) for the two sets of measurements are high, these will be averaged to produce the R2D:4D and L2D:4D values used in all further analyses.  If the measurements are found not to be reliable, we will use whichever set of measurements provides the lower standard deviation.  M2D:4D will be calculated as the average of R2D:4D L2D:4D, and D[R-L] will be calculated as the arithmetic mean difference between R2D:4D and L2D:4D (see (Manning, 2002).


3. Study 1: Assortative Mating on Autistic Traits and Related Measures

3.1 Hypotheses and analysis plan

H1: There will be sex differences for each autism-related variable
	Paired samples t tests to examine the difference in partners’ AQ scores (predicted direction: males higher than females)
	Paired samples t test to examine the difference in partners’ EQ scores (predicted direction: females higher than males)
	Paired samples t test to examine the difference in partners’ SQ-R scores (predicted direction: males higher than females)
	Paired samples t test to examine the difference in partners’ D scores (predicted direction: males higher [i.e. more male-typical] than females)
	Paired samples t test to examine the difference in partners’ RMET scores (predicted direction: females higher than males)
	Paired samples t test to examine the difference in partners’ EFT mean response times (predicted direction: males faster than females)

H2: Variables related to social homogamy will be positively correlated within couples
	Pearson’s correlation test to determine the association between males’ age and the age of their female partners (predicted direction: positive correlation)
	Spearman’s correlation test to determine the association between males’ educational attainment and the educational attainment of their female partners (predicted direction: positive correlation)
	Chi-square test to determine whether males’ STEM status is associated with the STEM status of their female partners (predicted direction: males working/studying in STEM will be more likely than chance to have female partners working/studying in STEM)

H3: Autism-related variables will be positively correlated within couples
	Pearson’s correlation test to determine the association between males’ total AQ scores and the total AQ scores of their female partners (predicted direction: positive correlation)
	Pearson’s correlation test to determine the association between males’ total EQ scores and the total EQ scores of their female partners (predicted direction: positive correlation)
	Pearson’s correlation test to determine the association between males’ total SQ-R scores and the total SQ-R scores of their female partners (predicted direction: positive correlation)
	Pearson’s correlation test to determine the association between males’ D scores and the D scores of their female partners (predicted direction: positive correlation)
	Pearson’s correlation test to determine the association between males’ total RMET scores and the total RMET scores of their female partners (predicted direction: positive correlation)
	Pearson’s correlation test to determine the association between males’ EFT mean response time and the EFT mean response time of their female partners (predicted direction: positive correlation)

H4: Intra-couple similarity for autism-related variables will be higher for actual couples than for random male/female pairings
	Within couple difference scores for autism-related variables will be calculated by subtracting the standardised score for females from the standardised score for males (for each of AQ, EQ, SQ-R, RMET, and EFT, respectively [note that sex-specific standardised D scores will be calculated separately]).  We will then compute random-pairings' difference scores for each of these variables as averages of all other male/female pairings that are possible within the dataset.
	Within-subjects t tests will be used to compare the observed standardised difference scores (i.e. for actual couples) with the average similarity scores for random pairings.
o	It is predicted that observed standardised difference scores for AQ, EQ, SQ-R, D, RMET, and EFT will be smaller than the corresponding average standardised difference scores computed for all other possible male/female pairings.

H5: Intra-couple similarity for autism-related variables will reflect initial assortment rather than convergence
	Pearson’s correlation tests to determine the association between length of relationship and intra-couple similarity for autism-related variables (i.e. standardised female AQ, EQ, SQ-R, RMET, and EFT scores subtracted from male standardised AQ, EQ, SQ-R, RMET, and EFT scores, respectively [note that the difference in sex-specific standardised D scores will be calculated separately]) (prediction: no correlations)
o	No statistically significant (i.e. p smaller than 0.05, two-tailed) association between length of relationship and the outcome variable will signify initial assortment rather than convergence.
o	Convergence may be indicated if there is a significant negative correlation between length of relationship and intra-couple similarity (i.e. with low scores indicating greater similarity).  However, it should be noted that greater resemblance within couples who have been together longer could also indicate that couples who are more similarly matched at baseline are more likely to remain together compared to couples that are more disparate at baseline.

H6: Intra-couple similarity for autism-related variables may reflect social homogamy (in regard to age and educational attainment) or active assortment
	Pearson’s correlation tests to determine the association between intra-couple similarity in age (i.e. female age subtracted from male age) and intra-couple similarity in autism-related variables (i.e. standardised female AQ, EQ, SQ-R, RMET, and EFT scores subtracted from standardised male AQ, EQ, SQ-R, RMET, and EFT scores, respectively [note that the difference in sex-specific standardised D scores will be calculated separately]) (prediction: no direction of effects predicted)
	Spearman’s correlation tests to determine the association between intra-couple similarity in educational attainment (i.e. female educational attainment subtracted from male educational attainment) and intra-couple similarity in autism-related variables (i.e. standardised female AQ, EQ, SQ-R, RMET, and EFT scores subtracted from standardised male AQ, EQ, SQ-R, RMET, and EFT scores, respectively [note that the difference in sex-specific standardised D scores will be calculated separately]) (prediction: no direction of effects predicted)
o	No statistically significant (i.e. p smaller than 0.05, two-tailed) association between intra-couple similarity in age and/or educational attainment and intra-couple similarity in autism-related variables will signify active assortment rather than social homogamy.
o	Social homogamy will be indicated if intra-couple similarity in autism-related variables is positively correlated with intra-couple similarity in age and/or educational attainment. 

H7: Social homogamy regarding STEM status will influence intra-couple similarity for autism-related variables
	Between-subjects t tests to compare intra-couple similarity in autism-related variables (i.e. AQ, EQ, SQ-R, D, RMET, and EFT) between couples for whom both members work/study in STEM and couples for whom either one or neither member work/study in STEM (prediction: similarity in AQ, EQ, SQ-R, D, RMET, and EFT scores will be higher in couples for whom both members work/study in STEM areas)


4. Study 2: Assortative Mating and Digit Ratio (2D:4D)

Studies by Manning (2002, p. 50) and Voracek, Dressler, and Manning (2007) reported statistically significant positive correlations between the digit ratios of heterosexual partners.  However, more recent studies (e.g. Kalichman, Batsevich, & Kobyliansky, 2019; Richards, Bellin, & Davies, 2017) have not observed such effects.  We therefore intend to meta-analyse the available data to determine whether or not such effects exist.

It became obvious from initial literature searches that using relevant search terms (e.g. ‘assortative mating’, ‘spousal correlation’, ‘partner correlation’) would not return some of the studies of which we were already aware that include relevant data.  The reason for this is that studies that have collected 2D:4D from spouses have rarely done so specifically to investigate the possibility of assortative mating (e.g. Hauth, de Bruijn, Staal, Buitelaar, & Rommelse, 2014).  For this reason, we do not intend to conduct a systematic literature review, but will use Review Manager (Cochrane Collaboration, 2019) to conduct quantitative meta-analyses for all relevant available data of which we are aware (including those of Study 1).  If a small number of studies with substantially different sample sizes are identified, we will compute fixed-effects models (i.e. to reduce the influence of imprecise small studies on the overall sample size estimate); if there is no large discrepancy in sample size (or we identify tens of relevant studies), we will conduct random-effects models.  Causes of between-study heterogeneity will be examined qualitatively, and the potential for publication bias will be evaluated via visual assessment of funnel plots.

4.1 Hypotheses and analysis plan

H1: R2D:4D will be positively correlated between romantic partners
H2: L2D:4D will be positively correlated between romantic partners
H3: M2D:4D will be positively correlated between romantic partners
H4: D[R-L] will be not be correlated between romantic partners
