attributes.title: Complex interventions for type 2 diabetes in primary health care at low- and middle-income countries: a systematic review and meta-analyses
attributes.description:
The International Diabetes Federation estimated that 425 million of the people worldwide have diabetes in year 2017 with a disproportionate distribution of 79% in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). The cost of illness of diabetes will pressurize the health system in LMICs as primary health care (PHC) systems are traditionally organized for acute care and the main sources of health care financing are through general taxation and out-of-pocket payment.

With reference to Declaration of Alma-Ata, PHC includes both community and primary facility-based care, ranging from promotive, preventive, curative and rehabilitative services. Targeting PHC is a sustainable and relatively inexpensive approach in addressing the issues that contributes to the loses in care.

There were systematic reviews on effectiveness of different interventions on diabetes care carried out at the facility level. Systematic reviews that included studies from developed countries showed that multicomponent intervention improved T2D care. Outcomes measured by most of the systematic reviews are intermediate clinical outcomes (e.g. glycaemic control) and process of care. Despite a large body of literature on different interventions on diabetes management, little evidence is known for LMICs with different priorities, workforce and financial arrangement. There is also a lack of evidence on the effectiveness of complex intervention in this setting. Hence, we would like to conduct a systematic review and meta-analysis to synthesize evidence on complex interventions for type 2 diabetes in primary health care setting of LMICs.

q1.value: Xin Rou Teh, Masliyana Husin, Sheamini Sivasampu, Liew Su May, Ka Keat Lim

q2.value: Review Question: Is complex intervention on Type 2 diabetes patients in primary health care setting effective at improving clinical and patient-reported outcomes in low- and middle-income countries?

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Systematic review and meta-analyses

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
Trials will be identified through systematic searches from inception of the following databases until date of search will be
included:
1. PubMed
2. Embase (OVID)
3. Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL)
4. PsycINFO
5. Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL)

There is no restriction for publication dates. Only studies reported or translated to English will be included.

References of relevant studies and systematic reviews will also be reviewed to identify additional eligible studies. In addition, grey literature including government reports and study protocols will be searched from Web of Science, Scopus, Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ) Grants On-Line Database and National Information Center on Health Services Research & Health Care Technology (NICHSR) from U.S. National Library of Medicine. Trial registries – ClinicalTrials.gov and ISRCTN registry will be screened to identify any on-going or unpublished trials. We will also search for published systematic reviews on McMaster University's Health System Evidence; we will screen the included studies of
these published systematic reviews to identify eligible studies for our systematic review.
If the identified studies are not available in full text, authors will be contacted to obtain the paper.

The preliminary search strategy is developed based on PubMed and contains medical subject headings (MeSH),descriptors and synonyms of the following terms: type 2 diabetes mellitus, primary health care, complex intervention, low and middle-income countries and trial.

This systematic review will include adults of 18 years old and above with a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes (T2D). We will extract the definition of T2D for each study (e.g. T2D diagnosed by physician, abnormal HbA1c, abnormal blood glucose) and will perform subgroup analysis based on the definition. Pregnant women will be excluded from the review.

Complex interventions targeting at primary care (facility) and/or community setting will be included in the systematic review. Complex intervention is defined as any interventions with two common characteristics:
1. multiple components (intervention complexity)
2. complicated/multiple causal pathways, feedback loops, synergies and/or mediators and moderators of effect (pathway complexity)

Complex interventions may also have one or more of the following three characteristics:
1. target multiple participants, groups or organizational levels (population complexity)
2. require multifaceted adoption, uptake or integration strategies (implementation complexity)
3. work in a dynamic multidimensional environment (contextual complexity)

Interventions that involve solely on pharmacotherapy will be excluded from the review.

All types of control conditions will be included, which are no intervention group, usual care or a comparator intervention group.

We will include randomized controlled trials in this review.

Abstracts and full text obtained from all the databases, grey literature and snowballing from reference list will be imported into EndNote, a reference management software. Duplication will be identified and removed.

After de-duplication, all the titles and abstracts will be screened by two independent reviewers (XRT, MH) based on the inclusion and exclusion criteria. Full text will be extracted for titles which fulfill the screening criteria or when there is uncertainty. Further clarification with the study author will be made if the uncertainty is relevant to determine the eligibility
of the study. When there is disagreement, both reviewers will discuss and come to a consensus. If disagreement persists, opinion from third reviewer (KKL/SS) is needed. Reasons of exclusion will be recorded. For final selection, all included full text studies will be screened against the inclusion and exclusion criteria. If there are limited access to full-text or if there are inconsistencies in reporting, we will contact the study corresponding author. If there is no response from the author after three attempts, within a month, the study will be excluded. The reviewers are not blinded for journal and author details. 

A standardized data collection form using Microsoft Excel spreadsheet will be used. Information that will be extracted include: year of publication, country, author, study design, T2D diagnosis definition, type of intervention, setting, target of the intervention, complex intervention definition, study duration, outcome measures, outcomes and risk of bias. Characteristics of the study population will be included: age, gender, weight, BMI, comorbidities, disease duration, baseline T2D control and medication use. The data collection form will be pilot tested with two studies by both reviewers and additional fields will be added if deemed important. To ensure consistency, an instruction manual for the data collection form will be created and used to train reviewers.
Not applicable

Primary outcome:
Change in glycaemic control, in terms of HbA1c or fasting blood glucose, will be the primary outcome

Additional outcomes include:
(i) Other clinical outcomes, which are the control of cardiovascular risk factors (blood pressure, body mass index (BMI), lipid), diabetes-related complications (eye, kidney, neuropathy, myocardial infarction, stroke), hospitalization rate, and mortality rate.
(ii) Patient reported outcomes which include health-related quality of life, functional status, symptoms and symptom burden, health behaviors and patient experience

Outcomes that include cost and not related to patient will be excluded from the review

Timing and effect measures: There is no time limit for duration of intervention.

If studies are not having high risk of bias and homogenous in terms of setting, participants, interventions, outcome measures and study methodology, meta-analysis and/or network meta-analysis will be conducted using R statistical software. Meta-analysis will be performed for primary outcome and any secondary outcome measures which have at least two similar studies. If the homogeneity of studies is sufficient, network meta-analysis will be performed.

For dichotomous data, the relative risk will be calculated with 95% confidence intervals (CIs) as the estimate of the intervention effect. For numerical data, mean and standard deviation and the differences between the means with 95% CIs will be reported as an estimate of the intervention effect. Heterogeneity will be reported in terms of I², and will be classified into low (>25%), moderate (>50%) and high (>75%) heterogeneity. If quantitative synthesis is not appropriate, only a qualitative synthesis will be performed. A summary of study characteristics and finding will be presented in tables and further breakdown the interventions based on the level which the intervention is targeted, either at patient level, healthcare provider level, health system level or involving more than one level.

q19.value: A cut-off value of 0.05 for p-value will be used to indicate significance level.

q22.value: If we have sufficient data, subgroup analyses will be performed according to different definition for complex intervention, different diagnosis criteria, study setting (primary care only, community, both) and duration of intervention.

If the identified studies are not available in full text, authors will be contacted to obtain the paper.

The preliminary search strategy is developed based on PubMed and contains medical subject headings (MeSH),descriptors and synonyms of the following terms: type 2 diabetes mellitus, primary health care, complex intervention, low and middle-income countries and trial.

This systematic review will include adults of 18 years old and above with a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes (T2D). We will extract the definition of T2D for each study (e.g. T2D diagnosed by physician, abnormal HbA1c, abnormal blood glucose) and will perform subgroup analysis based on the definition. Pregnant women will be excluded from the review.

Complex interventions targeting at primary care (facility) and/or community setting will be included in the systematic review. Complex intervention is defined as any interventions with two common characteristics:
1. multiple components (intervention complexity)
2. complicated/multiple causal pathways, feedback loops, synergies and/or mediators and moderators of effect (pathway complexity)

Complex interventions may also have one or more of the following three characteristics:
1. target multiple participants, groups or organizational levels (population complexity)
2. require multifaceted adoption, uptake or integration strategies (implementation complexity)
3. work in a dynamic multidimensional environment (contextual complexity)

Interventions that involve solely on pharmacotherapy will be excluded from the review.

All types of control conditions will be included, which are no intervention group, usual care or a comparator intervention group.

We will include randomized controlled trials in this review.

Abstracts and full text obtained from all the databases, grey literature and snowballing from reference list will be imported into EndNote, a reference management software. Duplication will be identified and removed.

After de-duplication, all the titles and abstracts will be screened by two independent reviewers (XRT, MH) based on the inclusion and exclusion criteria. Full text will be extracted for titles which fulfill the screening criteria or when there is uncertainty. Further clarification with the study author will be made if the uncertainty is relevant to determine the eligibility
of the study. When there is disagreement, both reviewers will discuss and come to a consensus. If disagreement persists, opinion from third reviewer (KKL/SS) is needed. Reasons of exclusion will be recorded. For final selection, all included full text studies will be screened against the inclusion and exclusion criteria. If there are limited access to full-text or if there are inconsistencies in reporting, we will contact the study corresponding author. If there is no response from the author after three attempts, within a month, the study will be excluded. The reviewers are not blinded for journal and author details. 

A standardized data collection form using Microsoft Excel spreadsheet will be used. Information that will be extracted include: year of publication, country, author, study design, T2D diagnosis definition, type of intervention, setting, target of the intervention, complex intervention definition, study duration, outcome measures, outcomes and risk of bias. Characteristics of the study population will be included: age, gender, weight, BMI, comorbidities, disease duration, baseline T2D control and medication use. The data collection form will be pilot tested with two studies by both reviewers and additional fields will be added if deemed important. To ensure consistency, an instruction manual for the data collection form will be created and used to train reviewers.
registration_responses.q14.question: Not applicable
registration_responses.q15.question:
Primary outcome:
Change in glycaemic control, in terms of HbA1c or fasting blood glucose, will be the primary outcome

Additional outcomes include:
(i) Other clinical outcomes, which are the control of cardiovascular risk factors (blood pressure, body mass index (BMI), lipid), diabetes-related complications (eye, kidney, neuropathy, myocardial infarction, stroke), hospitalization rate, and mortality rate.
(ii) Patient reported outcomes which include health-related quality of life, functional status, symptoms and symptom burden, health behaviors and patient experience

Outcomes that include cost and not related to patient will be excluded from the review

Timing and effect measures: There is no time limit for duration of intervention.
registration_responses.q17.question:
If studies are not having high risk of bias and homogenous in terms of setting, participants, interventions, outcome measures and study methodology, meta-analysis and/or network meta-analysis will be conducted using R statistical software. Meta-analysis will be performed for primary outcome and any secondary outcome measures which have at least two similar studies. If the homogeneity of studies is sufficient, network meta-analysis will be performed.

For dichotomous data, the relative risk will be calculated with 95% confidence intervals (CIs) as the estimate of the intervention effect. For numerical data, mean and standard deviation and the differences between the means with 95% CIs will be reported as an estimate of the intervention effect. Heterogeneity will be reported in terms of I², and will be classified into low (>25%), moderate (>50%) and high (>75%) heterogeneity. If quantitative synthesis is not appropriate, only a qualitative synthesis will be performed. A summary of study characteristics and finding will be presented in tables and further breakdown the interventions based on the level which the intervention is targeted, either at patient level, healthcare provider level, health system level or involving more than one level.

attributes.title: From Court to Classroom: How Shifts in Deportation Proceedings Relate to Academic and Non-Academic Outcomes for Elementary Students from 1998 to 2016

summary.value: Statement of Transparency (SOT) for a study that examined links between court-ordered removals (deportations) across the U.S. and academic and non-academic outcomes for students over the span of nearly two decades. The study focuses on pre-existing, secondary data from the Early Childhood Longitudinal Studies (Kindergarten Classes of 1998-99 and 2010-11). Registration of SOT comes prior to the cleaning and merging of data from the Census, the Transactional Records Access Clearinghouse, and ECLS datasets.
